Dialogue.NPCText:
Before you stands a wiry man bristling with contraptions: cogs in his hair, a cloak patched with blueprints, and a left arm unmistakably replaced by a copper teapot. The wizard's hat he wears is festooned with clock hands that spin erratically.

He squints at you, tinkering with a spanner, and grins crookedly. "Ah! A visitor! Or are you one of those Minax agents disguised as a visitor? Hmm. No matter. Unless you’re here to borrow my hands—number sixteen is a lefty teapot this week—you’d best state your business."

Option.text: What happened to your arm? Is that a teapot?
I heard you build magical engines. Need help?
How did you end up in Frostmere?
You seem… eccentric. Do you know Garrik?
Tell me more about your past, Grel.
I’m just looking around.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Grel flexes his copper teapot arm, pouring a faint trickle of steam onto the floor.

"Teapot, yes! A mark of genius or desperation—hard to say. Seventeenth revision, actually. Much more ergonomic than the ladle, and the inkwell model was a disaster.

You see, my original arm is... well, somewhere between here and the Wind Tower after a regrettable 'kinetic resonance test.' Master Pyrrhion still sends me letters, mostly curses."

Option.text: Do the locals treat you well, being from Wind?
How do you get along with Garrik the Blacksmith?
Let’s talk business. Need a hand?
You know, I like the teapot. Very distinguished.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Grel beams. "Ha! A discerning eye! This village is full of hammer-wavers and sticklers for 'tradition.' They’d rather swing a sword than wind a spring. You, my friend, have taste!

But if you truly wish to help, I do have a problem needing more than just a clever spout..."

Option.text: I’m ready. What’s the trouble?
Tell me about this place first.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Let’s see… banished from Wind for turning a meditation chamber into a steam bath, nearly eaten by frost wolves in the tundra, and rescued by Svala the Huntress—who only did so because she wanted the wolves’ pelts!

They let me stay because I fix broken things, make traps for the militia, and, well, they haven’t figured out how to get rid of me. Frostmere is odd, dangerous, and full of problems—my kind of place."

Option.text: Sounds like you fit in perfectly.
So, what’s the latest trouble needing a tinkerer?
I bet Garrik isn’t a fan.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Grel huffs, slamming a gear into his toolloop apron.

"Garrik! That man wouldn’t know innovation if it bit his anvil. Leather, steel, muscle—bah! He scorns my 'unnatural' devices, but half his tools are sharper thanks to my 'unnatural' whetstone gears.

He keeps to his forges and mutters about 'cursed magic,' but ask him where his frost-proof tongs came from! Still… the village needs both of us. Sometimes we even drink together, when he forgets to hate me."

Option.text: I think both of you keep Frostmere running.
Tell me, what needs doing?
I’ll be going.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Well, let’s see… Svala once set a bear trap for me (I fixed it so it wouldn’t snap). Bryndra rolls her eyes at my 'toys,' but her militia wears my clockwork braces in the cold.

The innkeeper Lira Snowbrew? She’s a true friend—lets me test my tea infusions, even the ones with a 12% chance to induce hiccups. The kids love my clockwork mice, the elders… tolerate me. Progress!"

Option.text: Glad to see you have some friends here.
You seem resourceful. Got work for me?

Dialogue.NPCText: "Looking is the first step to invention! If you see any suspicious gears, loose springs, or a rogue squirrel wearing a monocle—let me know. If you decide you want to make yourself useful, come back—I always have jobs for nimble fingers."

Option.text: I’m ready to help now.
Farewell, Grel.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Grel’s eyes dart about, lowering his voice conspiratorially.

"All right, here’s the thing. My latest invention—a 'resonance dampener' to stabilize the Obelisk’s energy—needs a critical part: the *inductive feather* of a GlacialEagle. Nasty creature, all talons and ice-wind.

The problem is, this particular eagle has taken a liking to my workbench. It swoops in, steals my tools, then drops frozen owl pellets on my blueprints. Last week it carried off my best cogwinder!

I’d fetch it myself, but last time I lost a boot and half a mustache. Would you be brave—or foolhardy—enough to track it down? Bring me its inductive feather and I’ll reward you with a tinker’s blessing. Or, well, at least something that explodes *only* when you want it to."

Option.text: I’ll hunt the GlacialEagle and bring back its feather.
A GlacialEagle? Are they really that dangerous?
Wouldn’t Garrik help you with this?
What will you do with the feather?
I’ll pass on this job.

Dialogue.NPCText: Grel claps his teapot arm to your shoulder. "Marvelous! The GlacialEagle nests up on the Frostspire Crag—careful, its cry can shatter icicles. And, er, try not to let it peck your eyes out. Return with the feather and I’ll let you test my Mark IV Warming Elixir… on purpose, this time!"

Option.text: Wish me luck! I’ll return soon.

Dialogue.NPCText: "Dangerous? Hah! Its talons are sharper than Garrik’s wit, and its breath can freeze a running stream. Legend says they once served as sentinels for ancient Obelisk priests—guardians of forbidden relics. I’ve seen it tear the hide off a frost bear, and rumor has it Bryndra’s best shield has a dent the size of its beak."

Option.text: I see. All right, I’ll do it.
On second thought, maybe not for me.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Garrik? He’d rather face a frost wyrm barehanded than help me with a 'magical nuisance.' He thinks every problem is solved with a bigger hammer. Besides, last time he tried, the eagle stole his lunch. He was so offended, he forged three new traps just to keep it away from his smithy.

But you—you have potential. And perhaps fewer grudges."

Option.text: I’ll handle the eagle myself.
No thanks, I’ll leave this to you two.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Grel’s eyes widen as if seeing equations in the air.

"The inductive feather channels ambient magical vibrations—it’ll act as a perfect conductor for my resonance dampener. With luck (and a touch of genius), it’ll keep the Obelisk from… well, shattering the village in a crystalline cataclysm!

Of course, there’s a *chance* it could do the opposite, but progress is built on small, calculated risks. Besides, wouldn’t you prefer an explosion with style?"

Option.text: Sounds risky, but I’ll get your feather.
I’ll pass on the risk for now.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Grel leans back, gears clicking gently inside his coat.

"My past? Well, that’s a mess of brilliant disasters and experimental explosions. Still interested?"

Option.text: Absolutely. Start from the beginning.
Maybe later. I’ll stick to your inventions.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"I was born in Wind. Not the calm kind, mind you—the floating city full of pointy-hatted arrogance and wards up the nostril. My parents were crystal mathematicians. Me? I tried to animate cutlery at age seven. Ended up with a violent soup ladle incident that earned me my first exile. Temporarily!"

He beams with pride.

Option.text: You were exiled as a child?
Animated cutlery? You’ve always been this weird, haven’t you?

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Technically, they called it 'magical quarantine for the protection of lunchware.' But yes. I spent most of my youth repairing old constructs, sneaking into libraries, and racing arcane beetles down drainpipes."

He taps his teapot arm, wistfully. "That’s where I built Prototype Arm #1. Made from bronze and spoons. Collapsed under its own brilliance after two hours."

Option.text: So when did things go truly wrong?
I admire your perseverance.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Rude! But not inaccurate. I consider it… *unorthodox brilliance*. Or perhaps brilliance that avoids orthodoxy like a flaming mongoose."

He crosses his arms. "Though if you’re here to mock, perhaps you’d prefer to test the spring-loaded trousers I rigged up for Garrik. They’re *very* expressive."

Option.text: Apologies. I’m just curious.
Spring-loaded trousers? I’m listening.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Grel sighs, dramatically.

"Ah, the incident. I call it ‘The Event of Unintended Levitation and Several Unpleasant Smells.’ My master in Wind, Archmage Pyrrhion, warned me not to combine resonance crystals with chronomantic tea leaves. Naturally, I did. The tower rang like a bell for two days."

He leans closer. "The good news? I invented a way to brew tea across time. The bad news? The tea was cursed and bit Pyrrhion’s soul out of his beard."

Option.text: That’s… disturbingly impressive.
You made cursed time tea?!

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Oh-ho! A brave soul. The trousers are powered by compressed wind essence and a small slap rune. Jump once, and you’re halfway to Aerilon. Jump twice, and you’re in orbit with frost gnats. Not entirely… safe."

He eyes you. "Maybe you *are* mad enough to be my apprentice someday."

Option.text: I’ll think about it. What happened after Wind?

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Indeed! I was trying to invent a drinkable chronometer. The result... well, it glitched reality by seven seconds and summoned a polite but menacing tea elemental. Pyrrhion was not amused. Or conscious, for a time."

He chuckles, tapping his head. "But it taught me something important: never trust leaves that shimmer *against* the wind."

Option.text: So that’s why you ended up in Frostmere?

Dialogue.NPCText:
"I wandered north. Built a few traps for nomads, fixed a collapsing glacier bridge, and accidentally gave sentience to a shovel. Eventually Svala dragged me here half-frozen."

He nods. "Frostmere didn’t trust me at first, but I repaired their waterwheel with a wind harp and a goose-shaped gear. Now I’m the 'eccentric essential.' I even get invited to council meetings! When they forget to uninvite me."

Option.text: What do you *really* care about, Grel?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Grel grins wide.

"You're the rare type that doesn't sneer at madness—er, *vision*. Much appreciated. Most think my ‘gearweaving’ is just ‘clock nonsense.’ But it’s heart and soul work, you know?"

Option.text: So what drives that passion?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Grel grows unexpectedly thoughtful.

"You want truth? I build things because I can’t stop. Because *creation* is louder than fear. Minax wants to twist the world—I want to reinvent it. One hinge, one spring, one teapot at a time."

He meets your eyes. "If I can leave behind just one invention that *helps*… that sings harmony against her madness… maybe the noise in my head will finally make sense."

Option.text: That’s noble. You have my respect.
You’re completely mad. But kind of brilliant.
That’s a lot to take in.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Grel tips his teapot arm like a gentleman’s salute.

"You’ve heard more than most. And you didn’t run, laugh, or confiscate my sprockets. That means something. If you ever want to build something truly ridiculous—and possibly world-changing—you know where to find me."

Option.text: Thanks, Grel. I’ll be back.
